required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on November 19, 2021
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: The Effect of Antihypertensive Drugs on Severity of Anaphylaxis and Side-effects During Venom Immunotherapy
clinical_study.official_title: The Effect of Antihypertensive Drugs on Severity of Anaphylaxis and Side-effects During Venom Immunotherapy

brief_summary.textblock:
There is an ongoing debate whether antihypertensive treatment with beta-blockers and/or angiotensin converting Enzyme (ACE)-inhibitors comprises a risk factor for more severe and more frequent side-effects during venom immunotherapy (VIT). In the literature, data are controversial and originate from case reports or statistically underpowered studies; the number of included patients was usually high but the proportion of patients on antihypertensive treatment was low ranging from 2-11%.
The study was conducted as a prospective, observational, European multicenter study. 1425 patients, aged from 35 to 85 years, with a history of an anaphylactic reaction due to bee or wasp stings, were included. The medical history was recorded as well as laboratory parameters and data of the VIT-updosing phase. One year after reaching the maintenance dose, possible side-effects during VIT as well as the outcome of field stings or sting challenges were documented.

primary_outcome.measure: Frequency of Side Effects (=Systemic Reaction, SR) During Venom Immunotherapy (VIT)
primary_outcome.time_frame: after finishing the updosing phase (duration up to 6 months depending on the updosing protocol chosen by the patient) of a patient's venom immunotherapy; duration of Visit ~1hour
primary_outcome.description: The primary objective of this study is to evaluate whether subjects under antihypertensive treatment with beta-blockers and/or angiotensin converting enzyme (ACE)-inhibitors show more side effects during VIT compared to subjects with no antihypertensive treatment.

secondary_outcome.description: To evaluate whether subjects under antihypertensive treatment with beta-blockers and/or ACE-inhibitors have more severe sting reactions.

secondary_outcome.measure: Correlation of the Prevalence of Cardiovascular Diseases and/or Hypertension With the Risk for More Severe Systemic Sting Reactions.
secondary_outcome.description: To correlate the prevalence of cardiovascular diseases and/or hypertension with the risk for more severe systemic sting reactions.

secondary_outcome.measure: Association of Bee Venom With a Higher Frequency of Side-effects (=Systemic Reaction, SR).
secondary_outcome.time_frame: after finishing the updosing phase (duration up to 6 months depending on the updosing protocol chosen by the patient) of a patient's venom immunotherapy; duration of Visit ~1hour
secondary_outcome.description: To evaluate whether bee venom is associated with a higher frequency of side-effects.

secondary_outcome.measure: Correlation of High Specific Immunoglobulin E (sIgE) Levels to a Higher Frequency of Side-effects (=Systemic Reaction, SR).
secondary_outcome.time_frame: after finishing the updosing phase (duration up to 6 months depending on the updosing protocol chosen by the patient) of a patient's venom immunotherapy; duration of Visit ~1hour
secondary_outcome.description: To evaluate whether high specific immunoglobulin E (sIgE) levels are correlated to a higher frequency of side-effects. sIgE levels are expressed in kilo units/liter [kU/L].

secondary_outcome.measure: Correlation of High Tryptase Levels to a Higher Frequency of Side-effects (=Systemic Reaction, SR).
secondary_outcome.time_frame: after finishing the updosing phase (duration up to 6 months depending on the updosing protocol chosen by the patient) of a patient's venom immunotherapy; duration of Visit ~1hour
secondary_outcome.description: To evaluate whether high tryptase levels are correlated to a higher frequency of side-effects

secondary_outcome.measure: Correlation of Quicker Up-dosing Protocols to a Higher Frequency of Side-effects (=Systemic Reaction, SR).
secondary_outcome.time_frame: depends on the protocol used for venom immunotherapy, a maximum of about 6 months
secondary_outcome.description: To evaluate whether quicker up-dosing protocols are correlated to a higher frequency of side-effects.

secondary_outcome.time_frame: 1 year after reaching the maintenance dose; duration of Visit ~1hour
secondary_outcome.description: The outcome (systemic reaction to sting or not) of sting challenges and/or field stings will be recorded to identify patients who will not tolerate but react to future stings. These results will be compared between patients not taking antihypertensive (AHT) drugs and patients taking AHT drugs.

secondary_outcome.measure: Correlation of the Prevalence of Cardiovascular Diseases and/or Hypertension With the Risk for More Frequent Side Effects (=Systemic Reaction, SR) Under VIT.
secondary_outcome.description: To correlate the prevalence of cardiovascular diseases and/or hypertension with the risk for more frequent side effects (=systemic reaction, SR) under VIT..

arm_group.arm_group_label: patients with a history of an anaphylactic sting reaction
arm_group.description: At Visit 1, patients will be included after carefully reviewing all inclusion and exclusion criteria. All data concerning the index sting, laboratory parameters like immunoglobulin E (IgE) and tryptase levels and skin test results will be recorded as well as the concomitant diseases and medication. Visit 2 will be performed after VIT updosing is finished. At this Visit data concerning the immunotherapy - premedication, preparation, updosing protocol, the outcome of possible large, local reactions (LLR) and systemic reactions (SR) and changes in diseases and medication will be recorded. One year after reaching the maintenance dose, Visit 3 will be performed. At this Visit data concerning the maintenance phase like premedication and possible side effects will be recorded as well as the outcome of insect stings.

intervention.description: Patients receive insect venom immunotherapy. The frequency of systemic side-effects is recorded and compared between patients under antihypertensive treatment and patients not taking antihypertensive drugs.
intervention.arm_group_label: patients with a history of an anaphylactic sting reaction

study_pop.textblock: patients with a history of anaphylactic sting reaction

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- History of systemic sting reaction (â‰¥ grade I according the classification by Ring and Messmer)
- age 35 to 85 years
Exclusion Criteria:
- absolute contraindications for VIT
- pretreatment with Omalizumab

facility.name: Department of Dermatology and Venerology, Medical University of Graz

provided_document.document_type: Study Protocol and Statistical Analysis Plan

group.title: Patients With a History of an Anaphylactic Sting Reaction
group.description: At Visit 1, patients will be included after carefully reviewing all inclusion and exclusion criteria. All data concerning the index sting, laboratory parameters like IgE and tryptase levels and skin test results will be recorded as well as the concomitant diseases and medication. Visit 2 will be performed after VIT updosing is finished. At this Visit data concerning the immunotherapy - premedication, preparation, updosing protocol, the outcome of possible large, local reactions and SR and changes in diseases and medication will be recorded. One year after reaching the maintenance dose, Visit 3 will be performed. At this Visit data concerning the maintenance phase like premedication and possible side effects will be recorded as well as the outcome of insect stings. Insect Venom: Patients receive insect venom immunotherapy. The frequency of systemic side-effects is recorded and compared between patients under antihypertensive treatment and patients not taking antihypertensive drugs.

baseline.population: Patients included in the study at Visit 1.

The frequency of systemic side-effects is recorded and compared between patients under antihypertensive treatment and patients not taking antihypertensive drugs.

measure.population: Race and Ethnicity were not collected from any participant.

outcome.title: Frequency of Side Effects (=Systemic Reaction, SR) During Venom Immunotherapy (VIT)
outcome.description: The primary objective of this study is to evaluate whether subjects under antihypertensive treatment with beta-blockers and/or angiotensin converting enzyme (ACE)-inhibitors show more side effects during VIT compared to subjects with no antihypertensive treatment.
outcome.time_frame: after finishing the updosing phase (duration up to 6 months depending on the updosing protocol chosen by the patient) of a patient's venom immunotherapy; duration of Visit ~1hour
outcome.population: 1342 patients underwent VIT and performed Visit 2. Of these 1342 patients, 93 experienced a systemic side effect during the updosing phase of VIT. Data were missing for 10 participants.

group.title: Patients Who Underwent VIT Updosing
group.description: Visit 2 will be performed after VIT updosing is finished. At this Visit data concerning the immunotherapy - premedication, preparation, updosing protocol, the outcome of possible large, local reactions and SR and changes in diseases and medication will be recorded. The frequency of systemic side-effects is recorded and compared between patients under antihypertensive treatment and patients not taking antihypertensive drugs.

measure.title: Frequency of Side Effects (=Systemic Reaction, SR) During Venom Immunotherapy (VIT)
measure.description: The primary objective of this study is to evaluate whether subjects under antihypertensive treatment with beta-blockers and/or angiotensin converting enzyme (ACE)-inhibitors show more side effects during VIT compared to subjects with no antihypertensive treatment.
measure.population: 1342 patients underwent VIT and performed Visit 2. Of these 1342 patients, 93 experienced a systemic side effect during the updosing phase of VIT. Data were missing for 10 participants.

class.title: number of patients with SR with AHT treatment
number of patients with SR without AHT treatment

analysis.groups_desc: It was assumed that 24% of the patients would be on Î²-blockers and/or ACE inhibitors (ACEI). A Ï‡2 test with a two-sided 5% significance level has an 80% power to detect the difference between the group without antihypertensive medication with 6% SR during VIT and the group on Î²-blockers and/or ACEI with 12.3% SR during VIT (OR = 2.2) when the sample sizes are 631 and 200, respectively. A drop-out rate of 37% was assumed which resulted in a required number of 1,319 patients.
analysis.non_inferiority_desc: All patients participating in this study belong to one of the following two groups for analysis: the group with antihypertensive treatment (Î²-blockers or ACEI) and the group without such treatment. The primary outcome was analyzed using logistic linear mixed models with a random intercept. This model type takes into account the clustered structure of the data, i.e., observations clustered in the different participating centers.
analysis.p_value_desc: The level of significance was set at 0.05.
analysis.method_desc: Missing at random was assumed, and multiple imputations were conducted with 50 imputations taking into account the cluster design.

outcome.title: Severity of Sting Reactions
outcome.description: To evaluate whether subjects under antihypertensive treatment with beta-blockers and/or ACE-inhibitors have more severe sting reactions.
outcome.population: 1425 patients were included in the study at Visit 1. Of these 1425 patients, 603 initially experienced a severe (=Grade 3 and 4 according to the classification of Ring and Messmer), systemic sting reaction. Data were missing for 2 participants.

group.title: Patients With a History of an Anaphylactic Sting Reaction
group.description: At Visit 1, patients will be included after carefully reviewing all inclusion and exclusion criteria. All data concerning the index sting, laboratory parameters like IgE and tryptase levels and skin test results will be recorded as well as the concomitant diseases and medication. The severity of the systemic sting reaction is compared between patients under antihypertensive treatment and patients not taking antihypertensive drugs.

outcome.title: Efficacy of VIT
outcome.description: The outcome (systemic reaction to sting or not) of sting challenges and/or field stings will be recorded to identify patients who will not tolerate but react to future stings. These results will be compared between patients not taking antihypertensive (AHT) drugs and patients taking AHT drugs.
outcome.time_frame: 1 year after reaching the maintenance dose; duration of Visit ~1hour
outcome.population: Visit 3 was performed with 1186 patients one year after reaching the maintenance phase of VIT. Data missing for 4 participants.

group.title: Patients Who Underwent VIT for at Least 1 Year
group.description: One year after reaching the maintenance dose, Visit 3 will be performed. At this Visit data concerning the maintenance phase like premedication and possible side effects will be recorded as well as the outcome of insect stings. The outcome (systemic reaction or not) of insect stings is recorded and compared between patients under antihypertensive treatment and patients not taking antihypertensive drugs.

reported_events.desc: All-Cause Mortality, Serious, and Other (Not Including Serious) Adverse Events were not monitored/assessed.

group.title: Patients With a History of an Anaphylactic Sting Reaction
group.description: At Visit 1, patients will be included after carefully reviewing all inclusion and exclusion criteria. All data concerning the index sting, laboratory parameters like IgE and tryptase levels and skin test results will be recorded as well as the concomitant diseases and medication. Visit 2 will be performed after VIT updosing is finished. At this Visit data concerning the immunotherapy - premedication, preparation, updosing protocol, the outcome of possible large, local reaction and SR and changes in diseases and medication will be recorded. One year after reaching the maintenance dose, Visit 3 will be performed. At this Visit data concerning the maintenance phase like premedication and possible side effects will be recorded as well as the outcome of insect stings. Insect Venom: Patients receive insect venom immunotherapy. The frequency of systemic side-effects is recorded and compared between patients under antihypertensive treatment and patients not taking antihypertensive drugs.

certain_agreements.pi_employee: Principal Investigators are NOT employed by the organization sponsoring the study.
certain_agreements.restrictive_agreement: There is NOT an agreement between Principal Investigators and the Sponsor (or its agents) that restricts the PI's rights to discuss or publish trial results after the trial is completed.
